top_categories.workout_context: Colorado Trail Race’s 530-mile distance demands power production deep into fatigue — the defining challenge of ultra-distance gravel.

Colorado Trail Race’s technical singletrack hiking trail — extensive hike-a-bike both uphill and downhill and competitive field demand explosive aerobic capacity — the ability to respond to surges without blowing up.
Every session at Colorado Trail Race intensity builds on this aerobic foundation — the endurance base is the soil everything else grows in.

Colorado Trail Race’s technical singletrack hiking trail — extensive hike-a-bike both uphill and downhill demands rapid power changes — surge over obstacles, settle on smoother sections, repeat for hours.
Racing Colorado Trail Race isn’t just fitness — it’s pacing, fueling, and executing when conditions deteriorate. This workout practices the race itself.
At 530 miles, Colorado Trail Race rewards a massive aerobic engine. This volume work builds the fat-oxidation capacity that keeps you moving when glycogen runs low.
Critical power determines how long you can sustain above-threshold efforts at Colorado Trail Race — a higher CP means more time in the red before failure.
Over-unders train the lactate clearance you’ll need at Colorado Trail Race when surges push you above threshold and you have to recover while still riding hard.
Colorado Trail Race’s 72,500ft of climbing demands seated and standing versatility — the ability to change climbing style as gradient and fatigue dictate.
Colorado Trail Race rewards athletes who can hold sustained power without blowing up — threshold is the engine that drives everything above Zone 2.

Short, violent efforts are unavoidable at Colorado Trail Race — climbs demanding 2-minute maximal efforts, surges to close gaps, attacks on technical singletrack hiking trail — extensive hike-a-bike both uphill and downhill.
Blended sessions combine endurance with intensity spikes — exactly what Colorado Trail Race’s technical singletrack hiking trail — extensive hike-a-bike both uphill and downhill delivers on race day.

race_overlay.heat: August in Durango to Denver, Colorado. Begin heat acclimatization 10–14 days before Colorado Trail Race — 20–30min sauna sessions or midday rides in full kit. Pre-load sodium 48 hours out. Target 500–750ml/hr with electrolytes on race day.
race_overlay.nutrition: Ultra-distance fueling for 530 miles: 80–100g carbs/hour from mile 1 — don’t wait until you’re hungry. Practice your exact race-day nutrition in every long training ride. Carry backup calories. 530 miles burns 8,000–12,000+ calories — you cannot replace them all, but you must try.
race_overlay.altitude: Colorado Trail Race with 72,500ft of climbing, much of it above 8,000ft demands altitude preparation. Arrive 5–7 days early for acclimatization. Expect 5–15% power reduction at altitude. Increase iron intake 4 weeks out. Hydrate aggressively — altitude increases fluid loss by 20–40%.
race_overlay.terrain: Highly technical terrain at Colorado Trail Race demands practice on similar surfaces. Ride technical singletrack hiking trail — extensive hike-a-bike both uphill and downhill at race-day cadence weekly. Practice cornering, descending, and power delivery on unstable surfaces. Dial in tire pressure before race week — 5 PSI wrong costs you 15+ minutes over 530 miles.

pack_summary: This 10-workout pack focuses on Durability, VO2max, and Endurance to prepare you for 530 miles of technical singletrack hiking trail — extensive hike-a-bike both uphill and downhill in Durango to Denver, Colorado.
